awd_titl_txt: I-CORPS: Assessing the commercial potential of reactive biofilm surfaces-based waste treatment technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of wastewater treatment technology aimed at managing nitrogen in liquid waste streams with carbon and energy efficiencies. Wastewater treatment plant managers are under intense pressure to manage nitrogen in their effluents because of surface water vulnerability to nitrogen pollution. With extreme droughts around the globe, protecting surface water becomes extremely important. Further, the proposed technology is aimed at managing the nitrogen cycle in the environment, which is one of the 14 grand challenges identified by the National Academy of Engineers.  The technology builds upon the fundamental science of reactor design and promises to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions from wastewater treatment plants.  The proposed technology supports the management of clean water while encompassing environmental sustainability through wastewater treatment designed with energy-efficiency and carbon neutrality.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a nitrogen management technology for wastewater treatment that incorporates energy and carbon efficiency. The proposed technology integrates anaerobic ammonia oxidation (ANAMMOX) with methane gas coupled heterotrophic denitrification (Denitrification And Methane Oxidation; DAMO) in granular biofilms to provide a compact and energy-efficient nitrogen management process. The proposed technology may accomplish low nitrogen in the final effluent and use dissolved methane gas to support denitrification, thus mitigating the challenges of greenhouse gas emissions (reduced carbon footprints). The proposed next steps are to evaluate the lab-scale prototype and develop a cost analysis plan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This I-CORPS project was meant to attend training and conduct a market survey for a proposed wastewater treatment technology. The training session was attended by the student (entrepreneurship lead), Dr. Sudhir Murthy (the industrial advisor), Mr. Tom Holstrom (Industrial Advisor), and the project PI, Dr. Ramesh Goel (technical lead). The following outcomes were obtained.

  1. The students obtain entrepreneurship and marketing training during the I-CORPs seminars.
  2. The student and the technical lead, Dr. Goel, conducted more than 80 surveys with potential technology users (municipalities), product vendors, and designers (consulting firms).
  3. The graduate student summarized the survey results, identified technology implementation barriers, and presented a plan, in consultation with Dr. Goel, to solve these barriers.
  4. Based on the training and surveys conducted under this project, the technical lead, Dr. Goel, could secure PFI funding from NSF to overcome the identified barriers further.
  5. The training obtained through the I-CORPS program and working on the PFI project helped the graduate student establish strong connections with the industry and secure a job in the wastewater industry.
  6. With the results obtained under this and the ongoing PFI project, Dr. Goel can submit further proposals to test the long-term sustainability of the proposed technology in a continuous flow-through mode.
